page.title: Pliny Section 1 :: Trajan's Reply to Pliny's Letter

link.text: See Pliny's Letter He Sent To Trajan

line.english: You have reported to me as you should (RECTE), my very dear friend

point.text: The superlative form of the adjective `dear` (very dear) indicates a very close relationship between Pliny and the Emperor

line.latin: Pertinet enim ad animum meum, quali itinere provinciam pervenias
line.english: for it is of interest to my mind, with what type (quality) of journey you are reaching your province

point.text: Repeating the wording of Pliny's letter, he assures Pliny that he does care about his journey

(of what kind) The Emperor is concerened not just with the fact that Pliny got there, but what kind of journey he had. Mabye Trajan wants to make such a journey himself, or mabye he wants to know the details of ease/difficulty/conditons to travel so he can apply it to EG: troop movements

line.latin: Prudenter autem constituis iterim navibus, interim vehiculis uti, prout loca suaserint
line.english: You have decided wisely to use somtimes boats, sometimes land behicles, just as the places have recommended

point.text: (rightly, wisely) The Emperor shows approval of Pliny's actions - this will please Pliny and reassert the Emperor's authority. Trying to be friendly yet authoritative. This is also the second time Trajan has been pleased by Pliny's actions (1: RECTE)

(as the places recommend) Pliny is being led by the demands of the Geography; this shows that he is an intelligent traveler, and flexible with travelling. This flexibility in travel may well translate into flexibility in governing (he is travelling to his province)
